title: Bertelsmann keeps 2015 forecast as TV and books fuel profit
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Mon, Aug 31, 2015, 09:28 BST - UK Markets closed for Summer Bank holiday Bertelsmann keeps 2015 forecast as TV and books fuel profit Reuters - UK Focus â€“ 43 minutes ago 
* H1 EBITDA rises to record 1.1 bln eur from 1 bln yr earlier 
* Hawkins (NasdaqGS: HWKN - news ) ' "Girl on the Train" sells more than 4.5 mln copies 
* Higher sales, EBITDA seen for full year (Adds details about book sales, CEO comment, background on RTL) 
FRANKFURT, Aug 31 (Reuters) - German media group Bertelsmann said on Monday it still expects profit and sales to rise this year after reporting record core profit over the first six months, fuelled by its television and book businesses. 
Privately held Bertelsmann controls Penguin Random House, a joint venture with Pearson (Xetra: 858266 - news ) that publishes the "Fifty Shades" series and Lee Child's "Jack Reacher". 
Book sales were driven in the first half of the year by Paula Hawkins' debut novel "The Girl on the Train", which sold over 4.5 million copies. "Grey" the new book by "Fifty Shades" author E. L. James, sold more than 3.5 million print, audio and e-book copies in the United States and United Kingdom in its first two publication weeks, Bertelsmann said. 
Adjusted earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation (EBITDA) rose to 1.1 billion euros ($1.23 billion)in the first six months from 1.0 billion a year earlier. 
"If there is no downturn in the global economy, we expect higher revenues and operating EBITDA for the full year due to the ongoing transformation of our Group," Bertelsmann's Chief Executive Thomas Rabe said in a statement. "In the medium term, we intend to significantly increase Group net income towards 1 billion euros," he added after first-half net profit rose more than 50 percent to 398 million euros. 
Bertelsmann also holds the majority of broadcaster RTL Group (Other OTC: RGLXF - news ) , which last week lifted its full-year sales forecast after regaining market share in its core German TV business. ($1 = 0.8909 euros) (Reporting by Harro ten Wolde; Editing by Christoph Steitz and Georgina Prodhan)
